Headline.Para: The Straits Times says; Develop primary care to meet needs

LeadPara.Para: Citizens would be gratified by the announcement that at least 30 polyclinics will be available by 2030, an increase from the current 20. Four would be opened in Eunos, Kallang, Sembawang and Bukit Panjang in two years. Another two polyclinics would open in Nee Soon Central and Tampines North by 2023, with four to six more planned elsewhere, including in the western and central parts of Singapore. This expansion is a worthwhile investment that will help bring primary healthcare closer to people's homes and keep medical costs down for the average Singaporean.

TailParas.Para: Polyclinics offer subsidised care for those requiring outpatient medical treatment and reviews after they have been discharged from hospital. Their services include health screening in the form of blood tests, X-rays and other diagnostic tests, immunisation, pharmaceutical services and health education. When patients are in need of specialised care, initial assessments are done at polyclinics before patients are referred to hospitals. For urgent attention, patients could go to private medical clinics and hospitals - which many simply cannot afford - or to government hospitals, which are obliged to assess all who arrive there.

Some of the pressure on polyclinics is eased by the Community Health Assist Scheme, under which those who qualify can get subsidised care at private general practice clinics. However, polyclinics must remain at the forefront of subsidised primary care to serve ordinary Singaporeans as a whole, given the rising cost of private healthcare. Although polyclinics treat both the old and young, they gain in importance as Singapore ages. The state of healthcare in an ageing society concerns the elderly themselves, those who look after them and, ultimately, the Government.

Not only will polyclinics have to meet keener demands for health services, but they will also have to play a bigger role in managing chronic diseases like diabetes and hypertension. Their ambit has been expanded to also include the early detection of mental health problems. In providing the first line of medical care, polyclinic doctors, nurses and support staff ought to be appreciated for the wide range of personalised services they provide, extending to even the treatment of acute conditions like upper respiratory tract infections.

With the greater emphasis on primary care, it is important to improve systems and professional capacity alongside the expansion of the polyclinic network. It can be taxing for the sick and their carers to have to queue for registration upon arrival, and then wait for long periods outside examination rooms or diagnostic facilities, before queueing up again to make payment, collect medicine and book further appointments. The modernisation of primary care must not overlook the processes that are part of the public system.
